nodes.text: A three-level probabilistic model (TRIDENT) that models error propagation at static-instruction, control-flow and memory levels can predict program and per-instruction SDC probabilities without performing fault injection, with accuracy comparable to fault injection and much better scalability
TRIDENT is implemented as a compiler module in LLVM and operates in two phases: profiling (dynamic) to collect execution counts and dependencies and inferencing (static) to compute SDC probabilities

TRIDENT decomposes propagation into three sub-models: fs (static-instruction level), fc (control-flow divergence level), and fm (memory dependency level), composed to trace propagation from a fault site to program outputs

Static-instruction sub-model fs computes per-static-instruction probabilities of propagation, masking and crash by approximating instruction semantics and operand statistics and aggregates them along static data-dependent sequences

Control-flow sub-model fc estimates probabilities that corrupted branch conditions cause control-flow divergences and computes probabilities that specific dynamic store instructions become corrupted due to branch flips (separately handling loop-terminating and non-loop-terminating comparisons)

Memory sub-model fm traces propagation from corrupted stores to program outputs via a memory dependence graph of loads and stores, pruning redundant symmetric loop dependencies and invoking fs recursively on static sequences encountered

TRIDENT inputs: LLVM IR program, one program input for profiling, and user-specified program output instructions; outputs: per-instruction SDC probabilities and overall program SDC probability (sampling instructions to trade time and accuracy)

Assumptions and fault model: single-bit transient faults injected in processor computational elements (pipeline registers and functional units); memory and control logic assumed ECC/protected; program may take legally incorrect branches but not illegal jumps; SDC probability defined conditional on activation

Evaluation setup: 11 diverse benchmarks compiled with LLVM -O2, ground truth via LLFI fault injection (single-bit flips) used for comparison, statistical sampling (3000 samples) used for overall SDC estimates and paired t-tests for significance

Result - Accuracy (overall): TRIDENT predictions of overall program SDC probabilities closely match fault injection (mean absolute error 4.75% across 11 programs; TRIDENT mean 14.83% vs FI 13.59%); paired t-test p=0.764 fails to reject equality

Result - Accuracy (per-instruction): TRIDENT predictions of per-instruction SDC probabilities are statistically indistinguishable from FI in most benchmarks (p>0.05 in 8/11 benchmarks); simpler models fs+fc and fs perform significantly worse

Limitations and sources of inaccuracy: TRIDENT omits special handling for bulk memory ops (memcpy/memmove), assumes only comparisons/logic/casts mask errors which ignores other masking instructions, conservatively treats dominated stores as corrupted, and faces difficulty analyzing corrupted store addresses

Result - Scalability and performance: TRIDENT requires a fixed profiling cost (about 15 minutes) and then incurs small incremental cost per instruction; it is orders of magnitude faster than FI as sample counts increase (e.g., TRIDENT 16 minutes for 1000 static instructions vs FI often hours/days)

Use-case (selective instruction duplication): Using TRIDENT to rank instructions and solve a knapsack selection yields greater SDC reduction for a given performance overhead than simpler models: example reductions average 65% and 90% SDC reduction at 11.78% and 23.31% overheads respectively

Comparison with prior models: TRIDENT is significantly more accurate than PVF and ePVF on the same benchmarks (mean absolute errors: PVF 75.19%, ePVF 36.78% vs TRIDENT 4.75%) because TRIDENT models control-flow divergence and memory propagation beyond static sequences
